instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.250A
threads.message:
Board had a shorted <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> line P3V3G3HRTC_PHASE1 after replacing that and all 4 CD3215s board now stays at 5V and 0.250A

I have all voltages all the way up to <SIGNAL>PMU_COLD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> working fine, <SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> and after (following the power sequence diagram) are all 0V

PPBUS 12.27V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> 1.8V

When trying DFU restore machine doesn't even enter DFU

Im stuck, any help will be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.250A
threads.message:
Do you get all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages?
If yes, try DFU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.250A
threads.message:
I forgot to post the rest of the info, here it is.

PPBUS 12.27V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> 1.8V

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE: 0.8V
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 0.75V
PVDDCPUSRAMAWAKE: 0.8V
P1V1SLPS2R: 1.1V
P1V8SLPS2R: 1.8V
P1V8SLPS2R: 0.8V 

When trying DFU restore machine doesn't even enter DFU

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.250A
threads.message:
"P1V8SLPS2R: 1.8V
P1V8SLPS2R: 0.8V"
This is very unclear for me.

BTW, I didn't ask to post these voltages.
If one is not good, tell us then.
If all are present, machine must be seen in DFU.
Be sure to follow all the steps in the tutorial linked on the forum.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.250A
threads.message:
Sorry  P1V8SLPS2R is 1.8V

I have never had issues putting a Mac in DFU, but I will try again tomorrow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.250A
threads.message: Ok just to get it out of the way I tried again to put it in DFU following the tutorial and had no luck, I even tried in a different Mac, different cable, different USB-C port board ( I swapped it with a new one ) but never enters DFU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.250A
threads.message:
Looks like T2 has an internal damage.
Probably caused by overvoltage through <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>...
